results.title: A Working holiday
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Hop picking in Victoria; seasonal workers gather from all parts of Australia for six weeks to harvest hops in the rich Ovens Valley. Shows the picking, bagging and weighing of the bags, and transport to the kilns. The weekend break is spent swimming, fishing or sight-seeing in the surrounding Alps.

results.title: Tjurunga: the story of stone age man. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description:
A central Australian journey was undertaken by the well-known naturalist, C. P. Mountford. On that journey he was accompanied by a group of Aborigines, who took him to their tribal lands and showed him the legendary rocks and caves and trees and streams, all of which are an integral part of the culture of the desert tribes. Mountford’s camera recorded on this journey some of the most beautiful country in the Australian continent - the lands of the original Australians. Companion to “Walkabout: a journey with the Aboriginals”. Originally filmed in 1946, revised in 1972.

This film, made in the Haast’s Bluff region, conatins ceremonial performances that are restricted and the film should not be screened without the express permission of the custodians.

results.title: Goodness - it's milk!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, promotes the dairy industry by proclaiming the benefits of drinking milk.

The film opens with some lovely footage of a couple exploring the Blue Dandenongs, including a milkbar with signs for ‘Peter’s Ice-Cream’, ‘Herald’, and ‘Four ‘n’ Twenty Pies’, where they order two tall glasses of milk.

The film then shows scenes of schoolchildren, a patient and nurse in a hospital and a domestic kitchen, while the narrator describes the health benefits of milk. The film finishes with footage of the dairy industry, from the farm to industrial pasteurising and bottling processes, and finally home delivery.

results.title: Aboriginal canoe trees of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Robert Edwards, South Australian Museum and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Aborigines of the lower Murray River formerly made large canoes from the bark of Red Gum trees. This film documents the felling of a canoe tree from the sides of the Murray and its transportation to the South Australian Museum for preservation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Edwards, South Australian Museum and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: The Drover's wife
results.brief_description: From Henry Lawson via Russell Drysdale - the Australian myth of The Drover’s Wife retold from a different perspective. Story retold by Murray Bail. Based on Henry Lawson’s original story and inspired by Drysdale’s painting of the same name this film explores women’s invisibility in our cultural history. It uses a wide variety of commentators and visual and literary sources, and is positive and free of professional jargon. Cast features Martin Vaughan. Won Silver Award and Special Award for Acting in the General Category at the AFI Awards.

results.title: Cherith
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Francine Penrose and Shirley Barrett
results.brief_description: Not being able to speak in tongues can be embarrassing at the very best of times. But if you are the only member of the congregation who cannot, and you are the daughter of a dynamic Revivalist preacher like Pastor Howard Spong - it’s even more distressing. And that’s just one of Cherith’s problems. This is a serious (and satirical) comedy about fundamentalist religion. This distinguished piece of film making, with a great script, direction and performance, won Best Short Fiction Film, AFI Awards in 1988.

results.title: Vasili's garden
results.brief_description: Welcome to Vasili’s Garden, a fun and very organic gardening show with lots of entertainment. Vasili enters people’s lives via the garden gate and together with the garden’s creator he delves into the private world beyond the backyard fence exploring their gardening obsessions and fantasies, sharing their tips and common sense. A tour around everyday gardens presented in both Greek and English with helpful tips and advice.

results.title: RAW. Episode 3
results.creator_credit: C31 Melbourne, Stephen Wools, Josh Lefers, Nick McInerney and Big Dog Productions
results.brief_description: AIRED 19 April 2006. RAW is fast becoming a cult classic. The show follows Josh and Steve on urban adventures and into social experiments: from racing trams and street sweepers, to stealing bibles and creating a revolutionary system of economy with their epic Freeshit ManTM. These boys will do anything as long as it is ridiculous.

results.title: Ticket, passport and tarot cards. Episode 18. The Star
results.brief_description: AIRED 29 December 2005 Based on a popular book from Tarot expert Linda Marson, this series is a a unique combination of personal diary, travel journal and Tarot imagery. Screened as a weekly show on Channel 31 in Melbourne, T, P and TC was a five minute filler program that screened from 1 September 2005 - 26 January 2006.

results.title: C News focus: Monday 22 May 2006
results.brief_description: Private lives of public figures. Aired 22 May 2006 this episode focuses on the media, and their coverage of the private lives of public figures. Independent MP Andrew Olexander is interviewed on what it feels like to be the subject of such scrutiny.
